description: From Anglo-Norman mortifier, Middle French mortifier, from Late Latin mortificō (“cause death”), from Latin mors (“death”) + -ficō (“-fy”).

verbs.description: mortify (third-person singular simple present mortifies, present participle mortifying, simple past and past participle mortified)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To discipline (one's body, appetites etc.) by suppressing desires; to practise abstinence on. [from 15th c.]
examples: Some people seek sainthood by mortifying the body.

entries.meaning: (transitive, usually used passively) To embarrass, to humiliate. To injure one's dignity. [from 17th c.]
examples: I was so mortified I could have died right there; instead I fainted, but I swore I'd never let that happen to me again.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To reduce the potency of; to nullify; to deaden, neutralize. [14th–18th c.]
examples: He  […] mortified them [pearls] in vineger aud drunke them vp

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To kill off (living tissue etc.); to make necrotic. [15th–18th c.]
(obsolete, transitive) To affect with vexation, chagrin, or humiliation; to humble; to depress.
examples: the news of the fatal battle of Worcester, which exceedingly mortified our expectations

entries.meaning: (transitive, Scotland, law, historical) To grant in mortmain.
examples: the schoolmasters of Ayr were paid out of the mills mortified by Queen Mary
